entry.title: Step-by-Step Guide to Creating a Custom Business Object in BOPF
entry.content:
Introduction 

The Business Object Processing Framework (BOPF) is an SAP framework that simplifies the development of business objects by providing a standardized way to handle data persistence, business logic, validations, determinations, and actions. Instead of writing custom code for every use case, developers can rely on BOPF’s reusable building blocks, ensuring consistency and reducing development effort. 

In this guide, we will walk through the step-by-step process of creating a custom Business Object in BOPF. Starting with the creation of dictionary elements, moving through defining the root node and generating dictionary artifacts in transaction BOBX, and finally testing our object in BOBT, you’ll gain a clear understanding of how to set up and validate your first custom BO. 

Steps to Create a Custom Business Object 
Create the Business Object in BOBX 
Go to transaction BOBX. 
Click on the Create menu option. 
Enter the Business Object name and description. 
In the Properties section, select Business Object. 

 

Define the Root Node 
Click on ROOT. 
Provide the following: 
Data Structure 
Combined Structure 
Combined Table Type 
Database Table Name 
Click Save. 
Double-click on the database table name. If it does not exist, create it explicitly in SE11.  

Generate Dictionary Elements 
Once the database table is created, return to BOBX. 
Navigate to Extras → Generate Dictionary Elements. 
This will automatically generate the required structures and table types.

Check and Generate 
Run Check and Correct in BOBX to validate your business object. 
Once validation is successful, click on the Generate button. 
The system generates the BOPF repository objects for your Business Object. 

Test the Business Object in BOBT 
Go to transaction BOBT. 
Select your custom Business Object. 
Perform test operations such as Create, Update, and Delete. 
Verify that the database entries are updated correctly. 

 

Conclusion: 

By following the steps outlined in this guide, you can successfully create, configure, and test a custom Business Object in BOPF. Using BOBX for modeling and generation and BOBT for testing, you gain hands-on experience with one of the most powerful frameworks in SAP for managing business data and logic. 

BOPF not only reduces manual coding but also enforces a structured, model-driven development approach, making your applications easier to maintain and extend. Once you are comfortable with creating root nodes and dictionary elements, you can explore advanced topics such as actions, determinations, validations, and associations to implement complete business processes.

1. Types of Internal Tables

In SAP ABAP (Advanced Business Application Programming), Internal tables are used to store temporary data during program execution.

There are three main types of internal tables in SAP:

  • Standard Internal Table
  • Sorted Internal Table
  • Hashed Internal Table

Standard Internal Table

This is default internal table type.

In Standard internal table, Table entries are stored in the order they are inserted.

  • Standard internal table are not sorted automatically. We have to use the SORT statement for sorting the table entries based on keys.
  • Standard internal table follows Linear search process for searching the records 
  • Here passing of data from work area to internal table is through APPEND keyword.
  • Standard internal table is not recommended for large datasets
  • Standard internal table accepts duplicate entries unless explicitly defined with a unique key.
  • Standard internal table is accessed by using index or key

Usage: Standard internal table is recommended only when sequence of fields are mattered or dealing with small datasets.

Example :  DATA: lt_standard TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF mara.

Sorted Internal Table

Sorted internal table entries are automatically sorted based on a defined key.

  • Sorted internal table follows binary search process for searching of records
  • Here passing of data from work area to internal table is through INSERT keyword.
  • Can enforce unique keys or allow duplicates depending on declaration
  • Here we must specify at least one field as unique or non-unique
  • Cannot manually sort or insert at a specific position.
  • Sorted internal table is accessed by using index or key

Usage: Sorted internal table is recommended for reading the entries based on keys

Example: DATA: lt_sorted TYPE SORTED TABLE OF mara WITH UNIQUE KEY matnr.

Hashed Internal Table

Hashed internal table uses a hashed algorithm for key-based access.

  • Hashed internal table follows Hashed Algorithm for searching of single record
  • Here passing of data from work area to internal table is through COLLECT keyword.
  • Fastest access for reading single entries using keys.
  • It does not accept duplicate records.
  • Only allows unique keys.
  • Hashed internal table is accessed by using key only

Usage: Hashed internal table is recommended for reading single entry from table by using key

Example: DATA: lt_hashed TYPE HASHED TABLE OF mara WITH UNIQUE KEY matnr.

6.Parallel Cursor

Parallel cursor is a performance optimization technique used primarily to enhance the efficiency of programs involving nested loops, especially when dealing with large internal tables.

Improve the performance of program.

Decreases the CPU and memory consumption associated with extensive loop iterations.

7.Control Break Statements

Control break statements are events inside the loop statement.

There are 5 control break statements in ABAP.

They are used within loop.(Except ON CHANGE OF which can be used outside the loop as well)

AT FIRST - ENDAT

AT NEW - ENDAT

AT END OF - ENDAT

AT LAST - ENDAT

ON CHANGE OF

AT FIRST: Will trigger at the first run of the loop.

AT LAST: Will trigger at the last run of the loop.

The below 3 events are normally used when the table is sorted.

AT END OF : When we use At end for a field, it will trigger whenever there is any change in any of the fields from the left to that of the particular field. The trigger point will be the at the last occurrence  of the same value for the field.

AT NEW: When we use At new for a field, it will trigger whenever there is any change in any of the fields from the left to that of the particular field.The trigger point will be the at the first occurrence of the new value for the field.

ON CHANGE OF: On change of it triggers only when there is any change in the particular field.

On change of can be used outside the loop too

  • In classical ABAP reports, messages are used to communicate information, warnings, errors, or success statuses to the user.

  • Message Types in ABAP
    1. Success - Type S - Displays the status of the program. ( Success message)

entry.title: BRF+ Object Creation using ABAP Z-Report
entry.content:
Introduction

When working with SAP BRF+ (Business Rule Framework Plus), Elements are the most basic building blocks. They represent data fields such as numbers, text, or dates, and act as reusable components for structures, tables, functions, and rules. Without elements, we cannot define or process rules effectively in BRF+.

In this blog, we will learn how to create BRF+ Elements programmatically using ABAP. This provides a scalable way to automate the creation of data objects and integrate them into larger rule frameworks.

Why Elements?

Describes data types of the variable. They are the data carriers helping in signature or context of a function, variables in a rule or rulesets, building blocks for Decision tables, Etc. You can create data objects by defining attributes like element type, length, decimals or you can directly bind to existing DDIC elements.

  • Reusability: Once created, elements can be used in multiple structures and rules.

  • Flexibility: Programmatic creation ensures consistency across environments.

    ABAP Program to Create Elements

    Below is a sample ABAP program (ZDEMO_BRF_APP) that:

    1. Creates a BRF+ Application.

    2. Defines three Elements (ELEMENT_1, ELEMENT_2, and CARRID).

*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*& Report ZDEMO_BRF_APP
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*&
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
REPORT zdemo_brf_app.

DATA: lo_factory           TYPE REF TO if_fdt_factory,
      lo_application       TYPE REF TO if_fdt_application,
      lt_message           TYPE if_fdt_types=>t_message,
      lv_message           TYPE string,
      lv_boolean           TYPE abap_bool,
      lv_demo_appl_id      TYPE if_fdt_types=>id,
      lv_string            TYPE string,
      lo_element_1         TYPE REF TO if_fdt_element,
      lo_element_2         TYPE REF TO if_fdt_element,
      lo_element_3         TYPE REF TO if_fdt_element,
      lo_table             TYPE REF TO if_fdt_table,
      lo_table_1           TYPE REF TO if_fdt_table,
      lo_structure         TYPE REF TO if_fdt_structure,
      lv_element1_id       TYPE if_fdt_types=>id,
      lv_element2_id       TYPE if_fdt_types=>id,
      lv_element3_id       TYPE if_fdt_types=>id,
      lv_input_number_id   TYPE if_fdt_types=>id,
      lv_result_counter_id TYPE if_fdt_types=>id,
     

FIELD-SYMBOLS:
  <ls_message> TYPE if_fdt_types=>s_message,
  <lv_value>   TYPE any.


PARAMETERS: pv_lcl  TYPE abap_bool RADIOBUTTON GROUP r00 DEFAULT 'X',
            pv_sys  TYPE abap_bool RADIOBUTTON GROUP r00,
            pv_mstr TYPE abap_bool RADIOBUTTON GROUP r00,
            pv_name TYPE char30.
*           p_ele_01  TYPE i DEFAULT 5,
*            p_ele_02  TYPE i DEFAULT 4,
*            p_ele_03  TYPE i DEFAULT 8,
*            p_ele_04  TYPE i DEFAULT 3,
*            p_ele_05  TYPE i DEFAULT 13,
*            p_ele_06  TYPE i DEFAULT 2.
*           pv_ele   TYPE char20,
*           pv_str TYPE char20,
*           pv_tab TYPE char20.

IF pv_name IS NOT INITIAL AND pv_lcl IS NOT INITIAL OR pv_sys IS NOT INITIAL OR pv_mstr IS NOT INITIAL.

* get a reference to the instance of the factory
  lo_factory = cl_fdt_factory=>if_fdt_factory~get_instance( ).

* =============================================================
* definition of the new application:
* get an initial application object from the factory
  lo_application = lo_factory->get_application( ).
  lo_application->if_fdt_transaction~enqueue( ).
* set values for the application, especially the name is important
* You need to have a unique name for each application, here we use the
* FDT Service class method to get the unique name.
  lo_application->set_application_component( 'BC' ).        "#EC NOTEXT
  lo_application->set_software_component( 'SAP_BASIS' ).    "#EC NOTEXT
  lo_application->set_development_package( '$TMP' ).        "#EC NOTEXT
*lo_application->if_fdt_admin_data~set_name( cl_fdt_services=>get_unique_name( ) ).
  lo_application->if_fdt_admin_data~set_name( pv_name ).


* In FDT terms there are 3 different type of Applications, Local application,
* system pplication and MasterData Application. The following lines shows how you
* can create local Application, masterdata Application and system Application.
  IF pv_lcl EQ abap_true.
    lo_application->create_local_application( ).
  ELSEIF pv_sys EQ abap_true.
    lo_application->create_system_application( ).
  ELSEIF pv_mstr EQ abap_true.
    lo_application->create_masterdata_application( ).
  ENDIF.
  lo_application->if_fdt_transaction~activate(
             IMPORTING et_message           = lt_message
                       ev_activation_failed = lv_boolean ).
  IF lv_boolean EQ abap_true.
*     for some reason the activation failed -> individual handling needed
    lo_application->if_fdt_transaction~dequeue( ).
  ELSE.
    lo_application->if_fdt_transaction~save( ).
    lo_application->if_fdt_transaction~dequeue( ).
*     usually it makes sense to store the id for later access to the application
    lv_demo_appl_id = lo_application->mv_id.
  ENDIF.
  WRITE: 'The ID of the application created is: ', lv_demo_appl_id. "#EC NOTEXT
ELSE.
  MESSAGE 'Provide all the required information' TYPE 'E'.
ENDIF.
*for creating Element,Structure,Table by Data Object


lo_factory = cl_fdt_factory=>if_fdt_factory~get_instance( lv_demo_appl_id ).
*                          if_fdt_constants=>gc_application_tmp  ).
* Note, that you are not required to use an application as input; however,
* we recommend to do so and work with a specific application instead of
* the generic local FDT applications.
*------------Element
lo_element_1 ?= lo_factory->get_data_object(
    iv_data_object_type = if_fdt_constants=>gc_data_object_type_element ).
lo_element_1->if_fdt_transaction~enqueue( ).
lo_element_1->if_fdt_admin_data~set_name( 'ELEMENT_1' ).

* set the element-type (see if_fdt_constants=>gc_element_type_* for
* a list of available element types)
lo_element_1->set_element_type( if_fdt_constants=>gc_element_type_number ).

******************************************************************************
* Alternately user can create an element using the service clas method
* CL_FDT_CONVENIENCE=>CREATE_ELEMENT as follows.
*
* cl_fdt_convenience=>create_element( EXPORTING iv_name = 'DEMO_ELEMENT_1'
*                                              iv_application_id = if_fdt_constants=>gc_application_tmp
*                                              iv_element_type   = if_fdt_constants=>gc_element_type_number
*                                              iv_activate       = ABAP_false
*                                    IMPORTING
*                                              eo_element        = lo_element ).
*******************************************************************************
* Set some attributes for the element.
lo_element_1->set_element_type_attributes(
  EXPORTING
    iv_length        = 6
    iv_decimals      = 2
    iv_only_positive = abap_false ).

lo_element_1->if_fdt_transaction~activate(
  IMPORTING
    et_message           = lt_message
    ev_activation_failed = lv_boolean ).
IF lv_boolean EQ abap_true.
* for some reason the activation failed -> individual handling needed
  lo_element_1->if_fdt_transaction~dequeue( ).
ELSE.
  lo_element_1->if_fdt_transaction~save( ).
  lo_element_1->if_fdt_transaction~dequeue( ).
* usually it makes sense to store the id for later access
  lv_element1_id = lo_element_1->mv_id.

  ls_element-position = 1.
  ls_element-element_id = lv_element1_id.
  APPEND ls_element TO lts_element.
ENDIF.

* Create another element
lo_element_2 ?= lo_factory->get_data_object(
    iv_data_object_type = if_fdt_constants=>gc_data_object_type_element ).
lo_element_2->if_fdt_transaction~enqueue( ).
lo_element_2->if_fdt_admin_data~set_name( 'ELEMENT_2' ).



* set the element-type (see if_fdt_constants=>gc_element_type_* for
* a list of available element types)
lo_element_2->set_element_type( if_fdt_constants=>gc_element_type_number ).

lo_element_2->if_fdt_transaction~activate(
  IMPORTING
    et_message           = lt_message
    ev_activation_failed = lv_boolean ).
IF lv_boolean EQ abap_true.
* for some reason the activation failed -> individual handling needed
  lo_element_2->if_fdt_transaction~dequeue( ).
ELSE.
  lo_element_2->if_fdt_transaction~save( ).
  lo_element_2->if_fdt_transaction~dequeue( ).
* usually it makes sense to store the id for later access to the application
  lv_element2_id = lo_element_2->mv_id.
  ls_element-position = 2.
  ls_element-element_id = lv_element2_id.
  APPEND ls_element TO lts_element.
ENDIF.

* create a third element
lo_element_3 ?= lo_factory->get_data_object(
    iv_data_object_type = if_fdt_constants=>gc_data_object_type_element ).
lo_element_3->if_fdt_transaction~enqueue( ).
lo_element_3->if_fdt_admin_data~set_name( ' CARRID ' ).
lo_element_3->set_element_type( if_fdt_constants=>gc_element_type_number ).

lo_element_3->if_fdt_transaction~activate(
  IMPORTING
    et_message           = lt_message
    ev_activation_failed = lv_boolean ).
IF lv_boolean EQ abap_true.
* for some reason the activation failed -> individual handling needed
  lo_element_3->if_fdt_transaction~dequeue( ).
ELSE.
  lo_element_3->if_fdt_transaction~save( ).
  lo_element_3->if_fdt_transaction~dequeue( ).
* usually it makes sense to store the id for later access to the application
  lv_element3_id = lo_element_3->mv_id.
  ls_element-position = 3.
  ls_element-element_id = lv_element3_id.
  APPEND ls_element TO lts_element.
ENDIF.
* WRITE: / lo_element->mv_id .
lv_string = lo_element_1->if_fdt_admin_data~to_string(  iv_mode = if_fdt_constants=>gc_tostring_mode_complete ).
WRITE : / 'The result of to string method call Element: ' , lv_string. "#EC NOTEXT

Execution & Output

When you execute the above ABAP report, the newly created Application and Elements will immediately be reflected in the BRF+ Workbench (/nBRF+). You can navigate to the workbench to verify that the application ZDEMO_APP and its elements have been created successfully.

After running the program, you will see system-generated IDs for each element created. These IDs are crucial when referencing the elements in Structures, Rules, or Functions.

 

Conclusion

In the next part of this blog series, we will explore how to create Structures using these Elements. Subsequent blogs will also cover Table, DB Lookup, Loop, Formula, Rule, and Function in detail.

entry.title: The Ultimate Guide to SAP S/4HANA Controlling Master Data
entry.content:
The Ultimate Guide to SAP S/4HANA Controlling Master Data

For End Users, Key Users, Beginners, and Consultants

Introduction

Welcome to your complete guide to understanding, creating, and managing Controlling (CO) master data in SAP S/4HANA. This guide is designed to be a single source of truth for everyone, from end users performing daily tasks to consultants designing and implementing the system.

Purpose of This Guide

The world of management accounting is foundational to making sound business decisions. This guide aims to demystify the core components of SAP Controlling, providing you with the concepts, step-by-step instructions, and integrated process flows needed to master this critical area. Management Accounting vs. Financial Accounting in S/4HANA

In traditional SAP systems, Financial Accounting (FI) and Controlling (CO) were separate modules. FI was focused on legal, external reporting (like balance sheets and income statements), while CO was focused on internal management reporting (like profitability, cost analysis, and budgeting).

In SAP S/4HANA, this separation is gone. Thanks to the Universal Journal (table ACDOCA), FI and CO are unified into a single stream of data. Every financial posting now contains all the characteristics needed for both legal and management reporting in one line item. This is a revolutionary change that enables real-time, integrated reporting without the need for lengthy reconciliation.

Key Organizational Structures in Controlling

Before we dive into master data, we must understand the organizational structure that contains it.

  • Operating Concern: This is the highest-level organizational unit in Margin Analysis (CO-PA). It defines the structure for analyzing profitability by market segments (e.g., by customer, product, region). An operating concern can be assigned to multiple controlling areas.
  • Controlling Area: This is the central organizational unit in Controlling. It represents a self-contained structure where costs and revenues are managed. A single controlling area can be assigned one or more company codes. This allows for cross-company code cost accounting. For our guide, we will use the example Controlling Area V000 for the "KPC Group".

Part 1: A Comprehensive Guide to Master Data

Chapter 1: Foundational Master Data - Cost Center Accounting (CO-OM-CCA)

Cost Center Accounting is where it all begins. Its primary purpose is to answer the question: "Where in the company are costs being incurred?" By tracking costs to specific areas of responsibility (cost centers), you can manage budgets, analyze variances, and control spending effectively.

1.1. The Cost Center Standard Hierarchy

Concept: What is a Cost Center and the Standard Hierarchy?

A Cost Center is a clearly defined location or area of responsibility where costs are incurred. It can be a department (e.g., Human Resources), a production line (e.g., Molding UP1), or a specific team (e.g., R&D Prototypes). You cannot post any costs without a cost object, and the cost center is the most fundamental one.

All cost centers within a controlling area must be grouped together into a tree-like structure called the Standard Hierarchy. This hierarchy represents the entire organization from a cost-management perspective and is mandatory. It allows for the aggregation of costs from individual cost centers up to the highest departmental and corporate levels.

1.3. Activity Types

Concept: What is an Activity Type?

In Cost Center Accounting, costs are collected, but we also need to measure the output or work performed by a cost center. This output is quantified using Activity Types. They represent the activities performed by a cost center that cause costs.

Examples:

  • A production cost center like "Molding" provides Machine Hours.
  • An assembly cost center provides Labor Hours.
  • A maintenance department provides Maintenance Hours.
  • An IT department might provide Support Hours.

Activity types are the link between cost centers and other cost objects (like production orders or projects). When a production order runs on a machine, it "consumes" the "Machine Hour" activity type from the molding cost center. This consumption triggers a cost allocation in the system, moving costs from the cost center to the production order.

The cost of this allocation is determined by the Activity Price, which we will discuss next.

1.4. Activity Price Calculation

Concept: Bringing Costs and Activities Together

The Activity Price (or "transfer price" in the source documents) is the rate used to value the activities provided by a cost center. For example, if the calculated price for activity type MA on the Molding cost center is $50/hour, then every hour of machine time consumed by a production order will be charged at $50.

The standard way to calculate this price in SAP is:

Activity Price=Total Planned Activity OutputTotal Planned Costs for the Activity​

This calculation is a core part of the annual budgeting process. The business first plans the total costs it expects to incur in each cost center (salaries, depreciation, energy, etc.). Then, it plans the total amount of activity it expects to provide (e.g., 10,000 machine hours). The system then performs the division to get the price.

Standard Business Process: Annual Cost Center Budgeting

  1. Plan Primary Costs: Budget the costs that come from outside CO, like salaries and supplies. This is done by G/L account for each cost center.
    • Fiori App: Cost Center Planning
  2. Plan Activity Output: Budget the total quantity of each activity type the cost center will provide.
    • Fiori App: Cost Center Planning
  3. Execute Price Calculation: Run the system function to automatically calculate the activity prices based on the planned costs and quantities.
    • Fiori App: Activity Type Price Calculation (corresponds to GUI T-code KSPI)

Converting the "KPC" Price Calculation Method to Standard SAP

The KPC source document describes a process of using the previous year's actual costs (first 11 months) to determine the budget for the next year, and then calculating the price. This is a common business practice that can be fully supported by the standard SAP process.

  • Instead of a custom report (Z-PRXCES): Use standard reports like Cost Centers: Actual/Plan/Variance (Fiori App) to get the actual costs from the previous year.
  • Instead of Excel®: Use the Cost Center Planning Fiori app, which allows you to upload planned data from a spreadsheet. You can download a template, populate it with the cost data (extrapolated for 12 months, as per the KPC method), and upload it as the plan for the new year.
  • Splitting Fixed/Variable Costs: The KPC method states that some cost types are 100% variable (e.g., direct labor) and others are 100% fixed (e.g., G&A, depreciation). This is managed directly in the Cost Center Planning app, where you can enter planned costs into fixed and variable columns.
  • Automatic Price Calculation: Once planning is complete, run the standard Activity Type Price Calculation app. The system will calculate the price and automatically split it into fixed and variable components, exactly as required.

How-to: Perform Activity Price Calculation

This is a multi-step process typically done by a controller or key user.

Step 1: Plan Costs and Activities

  • App Name: Cost Center Planning
  • Steps:
    1. Open the app and select a planning template (e.g., for Cost Element Planning).
    2. Enter your Version (0 for actual plan), Fiscal Year, Period range (1 to 12), Cost Center(s), and G/L Account(s).
    3. Manually enter the planned cost figures for each G/L account, splitting them between fixed and variable amounts as required.
    4. Switch to a different template for Activity Type Planning.
    5. Enter the Version, Fiscal Year, Period, Cost Center(s), and Activity Type(s).
    6. Enter the total planned output quantity for each activity type (e.g., 10000 H for MA).
    7. Save your planning data.

Step 2: Calculate the Price

  • App Name: Activity Type Price Calculation
  • Steps:
    1. Open the app.
    2. Enter the Version, Fiscal Year, and Period range.
    3. In the selection criteria, enter the Cost Center(s) or Group for which you want to calculate prices.
    4. Crucially, ensure you are running this in Test Run mode first to preview the results. The system will provide a detailed log.
    5. Review the log to see the calculated prices. The log will show you the total planned costs, the total planned activity, and the resulting price.
    6. Once you are satisfied with the results, go back, uncheck the Test Run box, and execute the calculation again.
    7. The prices are now saved in the system and will be used for all activity allocations in that period.

Step 3: Review the Calculated Price

  • App Name: Display Activity Rate Report (or check within the Manage Activity Types app)
  • Action: You can use this report to see the prices that have been calculated for any combination of cost center and activity type for the fiscal year.

Chapter 2: Profitability and Segment Reporting

While Cost Center Accounting tells you where costs are incurred, this chapter focuses on answering the question: "For what purpose was the cost incurred?" We want to determine the profitability of our products, customers, and other market dimensions. This is the domain of Profit Center Accounting and Margin Analysis.

2.1. Profit Centers

Concept: What is a Profit Center?

A Profit Center is an organizational unit that is managed like a "company within the company." It has its own revenues and costs and is responsible for its own profit or loss. Profit centers are the primary objects used for internal profitability reporting.

In S/4HANA, profit centers are also the source for deriving another crucial characteristic: the Segment.

Examples of Profit Centers:

  • By product line: Profit Center "Product A", Profit Center "Product B"
  • By business unit: Profit Center "Manufacturing", Profit Center "Services"
  • By geographical area: Profit Center "North America", Profit Center "Europe"

Just like cost centers, profit centers can be organized into a Standard Hierarchy for reporting purposes.

2.2. Segments and Document Splitting

Concept: What is a Segment?

A Segment is an organizational unit used for financial reporting, primarily to fulfill legal requirements like IFRS 8 and US GAAP. Segments represent a sub-activity of a company for which revenue is generated and costs are incurred. The goal of segment reporting is to produce a complete balance sheet and income statement for each reportable segment.

In SAP S/4HANA, the Segment is typically derived automatically from the Profit Center assigned to a transaction.

Concept: Document Splitting

How can SAP produce a full balance sheet for a segment if some line items, like a bank payment to a vendor, don't naturally have a segment assignment? The answer is Document Splitting.

Document Splitting is a powerful, real-time function in the General Ledger. When you post a document, the system analyzes it. For lines that have an account assignment (like an expense line with a cost center), it reads the profit center and segment from that assignment. It then automatically "splits" the other lines of the document (like the vendor and tax lines) and adds the same profit center and segment to them.

The result is that every line item in the Universal Journal has the necessary characteristics for balanced reporting. This enables you to generate a balance sheet by profit center or segment that will always balance to zero, in real time.

Customizing Point: Defining Segments and Activating Document Splitting

This is a configuration activity performed by consultants and is not an end-user task. However, it's essential for all users to understand how it works.

  1. Define the Segment
  • Method: SPRO (SAP GUI) or CBC (Cloud)
  • IMG Path: Enterprise Structure -> Definition -> Financial Accounting -> Define Segment
  • Action: Here, you simply create the segment codes and give them a description. For example:
    • 1000_A: Segment A
    • 1000_B: Segment B
    • 1000_C: Segment C
  1. Classify G/L Accounts for Document Splitting
  • IMG Path: Financial Accounting -> General Ledger Accounting -> Business Transactions -> Document Splitting -> Classify G/L Accounts for Document Splitting
  • Action: This is the most critical step. You must categorize all your G/L accounts to tell the document splitter how to treat them. For example:
    • Category 02000 (Customer): This is an item to be split.
    • Category 03000 (Vendor): This is an item to be split.
    • Category 20000 (Expense): This is a line that provides the account assignment.
    • Category 30000 (Revenue): This is a line that provides the account assignment.
    • Category 04000 (Cash Account): An item to be split.
  1. Define Document Splitting Characteristics
  • IMG Path: ... -> Document Splitting -> Define Document Splitting Characteristics for General Ledger Accounting
  • Action: Here you tell the system which fields should be split. You will specify Profit Center (PRCTR) and Segment (SEGMENT). For the Segment, you must tick the "Zero Balance" checkbox. This tells the system to ensure that for every document, the debits and credits for each segment must equal zero. If they don't, the system will automatically generate additional line items to a pre-configured clearing account to force the balance.
  1. Activate Document Splitting
  • IMG Path: ... -> Document Splitting -> Activate Document Splitting
  • Action: You activate the function at the client level. You can then deactivate it for specific company codes if necessary, but this is not recommended as it prevents cross-company transactions.

2.3. Dummy and Default Profit Centers

Concept: Ensuring Data Completeness

What happens if a posting is made to an object that doesn't have a profit center assigned yet? To prevent data from being lost to Profit Center Accounting, SAP uses a Dummy Profit Center.

  • Dummy Profit Center (KE59): When you activate Profit Center Accounting in a controlling area, the system requires you to create a dummy profit center. Any posting made to a cost object (like a cost center or order) that is missing a profit center assignment will automatically post to this dummy. This acts as a safety net. Controllers should regularly review postings to the dummy profit center and make corrections to ensure all master data is properly maintained. For KPC, this would be profit center YB999.
  • Default Profit Center (for non-assigned processes): In some business processes, it's not possible to derive a real profit center at the time of posting. For these cases, you can configure a default profit center and segment.
    • Customizing: Financial Accounting -> ... -> Document Splitting -> Edit Constants for Nonassigned Processes.
    • Action: You define a constant (e.g., Z1000), assign a default profit center (e.g., your dummy YB999) and a default segment (e.g., 1000_C) to it, and then assign this constant in the main document splitting activation screen.

Chapter 3: Margin Analysis in S/4HANA

Margin Analysis is the S/4HANA evolution of CO-PA (Profitability Analysis). It is fully integrated with the Universal Journal, meaning there is no separate CO-PA data table. Every profitability-relevant posting is updated in real-time in table ACDOCA. This allows for instant, drill-down analysis from a high-level P&L report right down to the original source document.

3.1. Characteristics and Value Fields

Concept: The Building Blocks of Profitability Reporting

In S/4HANA Margin Analysis, the structure of your reports is defined by two key elements:

  • Characteristics: These are the dimensions by which you want to analyze your profitability. They answer the "who" and "what" questions.
    • Examples: Customer, Product, Sales Region, Distribution Channel, Salesperson, Product Hierarchy.
    • Many characteristics are standard fields in SAP (like Customer from the customer master, Product from the material master). You can also define your own custom characteristics.
  • "Value Fields" (The S/4HANA way): In traditional costing-based CO-PA, you had "value fields" to store amounts (e.g., VVREV for revenue, VVCOS for cost of sales). In S/4HANA Margin Analysis, this concept is replaced by G/L Accounts. Your financial statement version (your P&L structure) is your profitability report structure.
    • Example: Instead of mapping a sales condition to a value field, you map it directly to a G/L Account like "400100 - Domestic Product Revenue". All postings to this account are then available for margin analysis, already tagged with the characteristics from the sales transaction.

The Power of Derivation

You don't need to enter every characteristic manually in a transaction. The system uses Derivation Rules to automatically populate them.

  • Example: When you enter a customer in a sales order, the system can automatically derive the Country, Sales Region, and Customer Group from the customer master data. When you enter a product, it can derive the Product Hierarchy, Brand, and Product Line.

3.2. Integration with Sales and Distribution (SD)

The primary source of data for Margin Analysis is the sales process.

  1. Sales Order Creation: When a sales order is created, the system captures all relevant characteristics (customer, product, sales org, etc.) and determines the planned revenue and cost of sales.
  2. Goods Issue: When goods are shipped, a financial document is posted. This document debits Cost of Goods Sold (COGS) and credits inventory. This COGS posting flows directly into Margin Analysis, tagged with all the characteristics from the sales order.
  3. Billing: When the customer is invoiced, another financial document is posted. This debits the customer and credits the revenue account. This revenue posting also flows into Margin Analysis with the same characteristics.

Because everything is in the Universal Journal, you can now run a single report that shows, for a specific sales order, the revenue from the billing document and the COGS from the goods issue document, allowing for real-time margin calculation.

  • Profit and Loss - Actuals: Standard P&L reporting that can be filtered and analyzed by market segments.

Chapter 4: Integration - The Heart of S/4HANA Controlling

The true power of SAP Controlling is its seamless integration with virtually every other module. Master data is the key that unlocks this integration.

4.1. CO <> Materials Management (MM)

The material master is the central source of information for a product. Its link to CO is critical.

  • Profit Center Assignment: In the General Plant Data / Storage 2 view (for manufactured goods) or the Sales: General/Plant view (for services/trading), you must assign a Profit Center. This assignment is the primary source for deriving the profit center in sales orders, production orders, and inventory postings.
  • Valuation Class: In the Accounting 1 view, the Valuation Class links the material to the G/L. It determines which inventory account is posted to during goods movements. This ensures financial transactions are recorded correctly.

How-to: Assign a Profit Center to a Material

  • App Name: Change Material (App ID: MM02)
  • Steps:
    1. Enter the Material number.
    2. Select the General Plant Data / Storage 2 view.
    3. Specify the Plant for which you are extending the data.
    4. In the General Data section, find the Profit Center field and enter the appropriate profit center for that material (e.g., material F1000 is assigned to profit center YB110).
    5. Save the material.

4.2. CO <> Production Planning (PP)

Production is where costs are consumed and value is added.

  • Work Center: The work center (a machine or group of machines) is the link to CO. In the Costing tab of the work center, you assign the Cost Center that is responsible for it and the Activity Types it provides (e.g., Machine Hours, Labor Hours).
  • Production Order: When a production order is created, it becomes a temporary cost object.
    • When materials are issued to the order, their cost is moved from inventory to the order.
    • When activities are confirmed (e.g., 10 hours of machine time), the system uses the activity price to calculate a cost (10 hours * $50/hour = $500) and allocates it to the production order. This simultaneously posts a credit to the production cost center, showing that it has provided output.
  • Settlement: At the end of the period, any remaining balance on the production order (variances) is settled to other objects, typically CO-PA, to ensure the full cost of production is reflected in profitability analysis.

4.3. CO <> Sales and Distribution (SD)

As discussed in Chapter 3, the integration with SD is key to Margin Analysis.

  • Sales Order: The sales order is the starting point. It gathers the characteristics and determines the initial profitability picture.
  • Condition Types: In SD pricing, condition types for revenue, discounts, and freight are mapped to specific G/L accounts, which then flow into financial reporting and margin analysis.

4.4. CO <> Asset Accounting (AA) & Project System (PS)

  • Assets: In the asset master record, you must assign a Cost Center. This ensures that when depreciation is run, the depreciation expense is posted to the correct cost center.
  • Projects (WBS Elements): Projects and their Work Breakdown Structure (WBS) elements are also cost objects. They can collect costs, have budgets, and be settled at period-end. You can assign a profit center to a WBS element to track project profitability.

  • How to Use: Follow each test case step-by-step. The "Prerequisites" section tells you what data you need to have ready, and the "Expected Results" section tells you what to look for to confirm success.
  • Data: Use the specific data examples provided from the KPC Group documents to make the scenarios as realistic as possible.

Scenario 1: End-to-End Cost Center Accounting Setup and Posting

Objective: To create the basic organizational structure for cost management, plan costs and activities, calculate an activity price, and perform a basic cost posting.

  • Test Case 1.1: Create Standard Hierarchy Nodes
    • User Role: Controller / Key User
    • Prerequisites: You have access to the Manage Cost Center Groups Fiori app. The controlling area V000 exists.
    • Steps:
      1. Using the app, create the following hierarchy under the top node V000: V000 -> 0100 -> 01003 -> 010031 -> 010031UP1.
      2. Create a second node under 01003: 010034 for G&A.
    • Expected Results: The hierarchy is saved and visible in the app. You can expand and collapse the nodes correctly.
  • Test Case 1.2: Create Production and Admin Cost Centers
    • User Role: Controller / Key User
    • Prerequisites: The hierarchy nodes from TC 1.1 exist.
    • Steps:
      1. Using the Manage Cost Centers Fiori app, create Cost Center 10031110 (Molding VP3) and assign it to hierarchy area 010031UP1. Use Cost Center Category F.
      2. Create Cost Center 10034436 (Human Resources) and assign it to hierarchy area 010034. Use Cost Center Category G.
    • Expected Results: Both cost centers are created and active. You can find them by searching in the app.
  • Test Case 1.3: Create Activity Type for Machine Time
    • User Role: Controller / Key User
    • Prerequisites: Access to the Manage Activity Types Fiori app.
    • Steps:
      1. Using the app, create Activity Type MA (Machine Hours) with unit H.
      2. Set the Activity Type Category to 1.
      3. Assign it to Cost Center Category F.
      4. Set the Allocation Cost Element to a secondary cost G/L account (e.g., 943000).
    • Expected Results: The activity type is created and saved successfully.
  • Test Case 1.4: Plan Costs and Activity Quantities
    • User Role: Controller / Key User
    • Prerequisites: Cost Center 10031110 and Activity Type MA exist.
    • Steps:
      1. Using the Cost Center Planning Fiori app, plan for the next fiscal year in Version 0.
      2. For Cost Center 10031110, plan $100,000 of costs on a primary cost G/L account (e.g., for energy). Enter this as a fixed cost.
      3. For Cost Center 10031110, plan an activity output of 2,000 hours for Activity Type MA.
    • Expected Results: The plan data is saved. You can run a Cost Centers: Plan/Actual report to see your planned values.
  • Test Case 1.5: Execute Activity Price Calculation
    • User Role: Controller / Key User
    • Prerequisites: Plan data from TC 1.4 is saved.
    • Steps:
      1. Using the Activity Type Price Calculation Fiori app, execute the calculation for your cost center and fiscal year.
      2. Run it in "Test Run" mode first and review the log.
      3. Execute it in "Update Run" mode to save the price.
    • Expected Results: The system should calculate a price of $50/hour ($100,000 / 2,000 hours). You can verify this in the Display Activity Rate Report.
  • Test Case 1.6: Post a Vendor Invoice to a Cost Center
    • User Role: Accounts Payable Clerk / End User
    • Prerequisites: Cost Center 10034436 (Human Resources) exists. A vendor master record exists.
    • Steps:
      1. Using the Fiori app Create Incoming Invoices (or GUI FB60), post a vendor invoice for office supplies for $500.
      2. On the G/L account line item for the expense, enter 10034436 in the Cost Center field.
    • Expected Results: The invoice posts successfully. Run the Display Cost Line Items - Actual report for the cost center to see the $500 posting. The Universal Journal (ACDOCA) will show this line item with the cost center populated.

Scenario 2: End-to-End Segment Reporting Setup and Verification

Objective: To create profit centers, assign them to other objects, and post a document to verify that Document Splitting correctly derives the profit center and segment for a balanced financial statement.

  • Test Case 2.1: Create Profit Center and Hierarchy
    • User Role: Controller / Key User
    • Prerequisites: Access to Manage Profit Center Groups and Manage Profit Centers apps. A Segment 1000_A has been configured.
    • Steps:
      1. Create a Profit Center Group YBH111 (Product).
      2. Create Profit Center YB110 (Product A) and assign it to group YBH111.
      3. In the master data for YB110, assign Segment 1000_A.
      4. Activate the profit center.
    • Expected Results: The profit center is created and active.
  • Test Case 2.2: Assign Profit Center to a Cost Center
    • User Role: Controller / Key User
    • Prerequisites: Profit Center YB110 and Cost Center 10031110 exist.
    • Steps:
      1. Using the Manage Cost Centers app, open Cost Center 10031110 in change mode.
      2. In the General Information section, enter YB110 into the Profit Center field.
      3. Save the change.
    • Expected Results: The assignment is saved. Now, any posting to this cost center will automatically derive this profit center.
  • Test Case 2.3: Post a G/L Document and Verify Splitting
    • User Role: General Ledger Accountant
    • Prerequisites: Document Splitting is active. Cost Center 10031110 is assigned to Profit Center YB110.
    • Steps:
      1. Using the Post General Journal Entries Fiori app, post a simple expense document.
      2. Line 1 (Debit): An expense G/L account for $1,000. Assign Cost Center 10031110.
      3. Line 2 (Credit): A bank clearing G/L account for $1,000. Do not enter a cost center or profit center here.
      4. Simulate the posting by clicking the "Simulate" button.
      5. Switch to the "Simulation in General Ledger" view.
    • Expected Results: In the General Ledger view, you will see that Line 2 (the bank clearing line) has been "split" and the system has automatically populated it with Profit Center YB110 and Segment 1000_A, which it derived from the cost center on Line 1. The document is balanced by profit center and segment.
  • Test Case 2.4: Run a Balance Sheet by Segment
    • User Role: Controller / Financial Analyst
    • Prerequisites: The posting from TC 2.3 is complete.
    • Steps:
      1. Using the Balance Sheet/Income Statement Fiori app, run the report.
      2. Add "Segment" as a filter or a row/column in the report layout.
      3. Filter for Segment 1000_A.
    • Expected Results: The report should run successfully. The total of all debits and credits for Segment 1000_A should be zero. This proves that Document Splitting is working correctly.

Scenario 3: Integrated Order-to-Cash with Margin Analysis

Objective: To test the flow of data from a sales transaction through to profitability reporting.

  • Test Case 3.1: Assign Profit Center to Material
    • User Role: Master Data Specialist
    • Prerequisites: Material master F1000 and Profit Center YB110 exist.
    • Steps:
      1. Using the Change Material app (MM02), assign Profit Center YB110 to material F1000 in the General Plant Data / Storage 2 view for your plant.
    • Expected Results: The assignment is saved.
  • Test Case 3.2: Create a Sales Order
    • User Role: Sales Administrator
    • Prerequisites: Material F1000 is maintained for sales. A customer master exists. Pricing is maintained.
    • Steps:
      1. Using the Create Sales Orders Fiori app, create a new order for your customer for 10 units of material F1000.
      2. Navigate to the item level details. Check the Account Assignment tab.
    • Expected Results: The system should automatically determine the Profit Center (YB110) from the material master. The system will also generate a Profitability Segment number, which is a unique combination of all derived characteristics (customer, product, profit center, etc.).
  • Test Case 3.3: Post Goods Issue and Create Invoice
    • User Role: Warehouse Clerk / Billing Clerk
    • Prerequisites: The sales order from TC 3.2 exists. There is stock for material F1000.
    • Steps:
      1. Create an outbound delivery for the sales order and post the Goods Issue.
      2. Create a billing document (invoice) for the delivery.
    • Expected Results: Two financial documents are created. The Goods Issue document posts the Cost of Goods Sold. The Billing document posts the Revenue. Both documents in the Universal Journal will be stamped with the same Profitability Segment number from the sales order.
  • Test Case 3.4: Analyze the Margin
    • User Role: Controller / Analyst
    • Prerequisites: All steps in Scenario 3 are complete.
    • Steps:
      1. Open the Market Segments - Actuals Fiori app.
      2. In the selection screen, filter by the Sales Order number you created.
      3. Execute the report.
    • Expected Results: The report displays the key figures for that sales order. You should see the Revenue amount from the invoice and the Cost of Goods Sold amount from the goods issue. You can see the calculated margin. You can add characteristics like "Customer" and "Product" to the report rows to see the details. This confirms the end-to-end data flow into Margin Analysis.

Scenario 4: Integrated Plan-to-Produce with Cost Object Controlling

Objective: To test the link between a production cost center and a production order.

  • Test Case 4.1: Assign Cost Center to Work Center
    • User Role: Production Planner / Master Data Specialist
    • Prerequisites: Cost Center 10031110 and Activity Type MA exist.
    • Steps:
      1. Using the Change Work Center app (CR02), create or change a machine work center.
      2. Go to the Costing tab.
      3. Enter the Cost Center 10031110.
      4. In the activity type assignment section, link Activity Type MA and enter a formula to calculate the machine time required for production.
    • Expected Results: The work center is correctly linked to the cost center and its activity.
  • Test Case 4.2: Confirm Production Activities
    • User Role: Production Supervisor
    • Prerequisites: A production order has been created which uses the work center from TC 4.1. The activity price from Scenario 1 has been calculated ($50/hr).
    • Steps:
      1. Using the Confirm Production Order Operation Fiori app, confirm that you have completed work on the order.
      2. Enter a quantity of 5 hours for the activity MA (Machine Hours).
    • Expected Results:
      1. A controlling document is posted.
      2. The Production Order is debited with 5 hours * $50/hr = $250.
      3. The Cost Center 10031110 is credited with $250.
      4. You can verify this by looking at the costs on the production order and by running a Cost Centers: Plan/Actual report, which will now show an actual credit, reducing the cost center's variance.

entry.title: SAP API ManagementのアクセスログをSAP Cloud Loggingで可視化する方法
entry.content:
背景：API Managementのログが見えない問題

SAP API Managementでは、APIの公開・キー制御・レート制限・トラフィック制御といった機能を提供していますが、呼び出しログ（APIのアクセス状況・Header・Bodyの内容など）は、Integration Suiteの標準画面からは確認できません。

  • Integration Flowのログは見られるが、API Proxyのログは対象外

  • サマリーの情報(特定の期間で何回APIが呼び出されたか)などは標準ダッシュボードで見れる

  • Auditログやトレースログが存在しないため、API KeyやJWTなどの認証問題のトラブル解析が難しい

  • アクセス元IP、User-Agent、Headerの中身などを確認できない

このような背景から、API呼び出しの可視性向上を目的にCloud Loggingへの転送が必要とされます。

下図のように、個別のAPIの実行ログは見られないのです。(開発中であればAPI Policyのデバッグをすればよいのですが)

 

解決策：Cloud Logging（Syslog Drain）への転送

SAP BTPのCloud Foundry環境では、Cloud Loggingインスタンスにログを集約することが可能です。
API Managementのアクセスログも、カスタムログ出力（AssignMessage + MessageLogging）＋ syslog drain構成によりCloud Loggingに転送できます。

この構成を取ることで：

  • APIアクセスログを時系列に保存

  • BTP Logging UIやOpenTelemetry連携で全文検索・ダッシュボード表示

  • 障害解析や不正アクセス監視にも利用可能

 

補足説明：Cloud Loggingへのログ転送の簡易確認

Cloud LoggingにはCloud Foundryのログを出力する以外に、PUTリクエストでメッセージを突っ込むことができます。
例としてPostmanから下記のJSONメッセージをCloud Loggingに突っ込んでみます。
リクエスト：PUT
リクエストURL：Cloud LoggingのService Keyの[ingest-endpoint]

下図のように、Cloud Loggingにメッセージが保存されていることがわかります。

ということは、API ManagementのAPI Policyで、Service Calloutを利用し、上記と同様にCloud Loggingへのログ転送を行えばログが見えない問題を解決できると考えます。


API Policyの設定一例

<!-- AssignMessageで構造化ログ -->
<AssignMessage ...>
    <Set>
        <Payload contentType="application/json">
            {
                "path": "{request.path}",
                "ip": "{request.header.X-Forwarded-For}",
                "timestamp": "{system.timestamp}",
                "userAgent": "{request.header.User-Agent}"
            }
        </Payload>
    </Set>
    <AssignTo type="request" createNew="false"/>
</AssignMessage>

まとめ

SAP API Managementは非常に便利なAPI公開基盤ですが、アクセスログの可視性には課題があります。
本記事で紹介したように、Cloud Loggingとの組み合わせにより可視性を補完することが可能です。

  • Integration Suite UIで見えないログもCloud Loggingで一元管理

  • API Policyからカスタムログ出力

  • Syslog DrainでCloud Loggingへ転送

運用・セキュリティ両面で非常に有用な構成ではないかと考えています。

Hello @MT1208 

Thank you for bringing this up. In SAP S/4HANA Public cloud, the "Posted to Stock" filter in Create Physical Inventory Documents can only be hidden if it was initially optional and subsequently made mandatory through Adapt UI. If the app enforces the filter as mandatory, it cannot be removed. The practical workaround is to utilise variants, allowing users to avoid seeing it prompted SAP Learning-Simplifying Physical Inventory

If the app is mandatory: create a default filter option with the selected value Yes/N) and enable 'Apply Automatically' so the app opens with that setting without user input. If both options are needed, create two separate filters variants/tiles SAP Learning-Using Variant Management

Adapt UI (Key User) – how to modify filter bar settings and publish SAP Help Portal

Set Variant Management as Default and Apply Automatically, SAP Learning: Using Variant Management

Spaces and Pages – for tile placement. Note: Hiding a tile does not alter authorisation. SAP Help Portal

entry.title: Re: Is it possible to add the Services Rendered Date fiel...
entry.content:
Hello @kezelda 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at Journal Entry Analyzer, Custom Business Objects, Fields, and Logic & Custom Analytical Queries for more details

In summary, the Services Rendered Date is not included by default in the Journal Entry Analyser. However, there are two options you can consider:

  • First is to check through the Custom Fields and Logic and see if the field is available in the Account Document Line Item business context and enable it.
  • Second option is to use the custom analytical queries by creating a custom query as a data source. You can add the Service Rendered Date if exposed in that CDS view. Your custom query can thereafter be published as a Fiori app similar to Journal Entry Analyser.

If the filed is still not exposed after those steps, consider raising a request via customer influence portal.

I hope this provides the desired insight.

Best regards

Chris
